data.title: The tragic history of Letchworth State Park: Fatal accidents, disasters, more
data.meta_description: Here's a history of some fatal incidents in the park's history.
data.text:
Photo: Scott Schild

The tragic history of Letchworth State Park

Letchworth State Park is one of the most beautiful natural areas in the country -- voted the best state park in America in fact. But with that beauty comes a tragic history of accidents, disasters and more. Here's a history of fatal incidents in the park's history, some to serve as a reminder to always be careful and use your best judgment when visiting.

User submitted photo | Michael Tracy

May 1865

The Portage Wooden Bridge in Letchworth is iconic, but working on it resulted in at least one death. Luther Stanton lost his balance while working on the high railroad bridge, and fell to his death, according to LetchworthParkHistory.com.

Read more

Photo: Screengrab from LetchworthParkHistory.com

July 4, 1876

A tornado ripped through Letchworth and neighboring area, destroying more than a dozen buildings and injuring many others, according to LetchworkParkHistory.com. There was one fatality: a young boy named Matson, aged 7 or 8, was found dead after the storm, presumably killed instantly as his back broke.

Read more

Photo courtesy of Matt Champlain

March 1903

For many years two trains–the Erie and Pennsylvania Railroads—ran through the park, resulting in many wrecks, according to LetchworthParkHistory.com. One of those wrecks resulted in W.E. Potts of Olean being pinned against the boiler head by a freight car. He was pinned for four hours, with his legs crushed and almost his entire body scalded. He later succumbed to his injuries.

Read more

Photo: Screengrab from LetchworthParkHistory.com

August 1917

An automobile filled with 11 people plunged over an embankment near upper Portage Falls, resulting in two deaths, according to LetchworthParkHistory.com. "The car in its descent turned twice over, end for end, run out into the river in shallow water right side up and headed in the same direction as when it went over the bank," the Rochester Times Union reported. Evienia Tomanovitch died at the scene and Grace Dillon later died at an area hospital.

Read more

July 1936

A fisherman found the body of Peter Willowry in the Genesee River Gorge. He had gone missing in February from a camp. It was believed he broke through the ice in an attempt to cross the river.

Provided photo

July 8, 1987

Christopher Konter, 15, was swimming in the river when he was swept over the Lower Falls. His body resurfaced and was found three days later. According to his sibling, Chris was visiting the park with two teenage friends. He tried to cross the river. When he realized he couldn't make it, he reached for his friends hand, slipped and he went over.

Read more

August 1992

Pamela S. Stone, 23, was attending a friend’s wedding at Letchworth when she fell to her death in the gorge at the park. She had been drinking when she was reportedly straddling a stone wall beside the gorge and fell backward and landed on the ledge. She fell off the ledge before she could be saved.

October 13, 2001

William Kash, 26, died from injuries suffered from a fall at Letchworth. He was a senior at St. John Fisher College in Rochester.

July 30, 2006

Adam Elliott, 18, slipped and fell into the water near Lower Falls while he was hiking. He was at the state park with a group from Portville Baptist Church. According to reports, Elliott was apparently hiking off the marked trails at the southern end of the park.

Read more

Photo: The Associated Press

July 3, 2010

Andrew Brinkman, a 19-year-old man from Amherst, died after a 300-foot plunge into a gorge at Letchworth. He was walking along a stone retaining wall at the gorge rim near the top of the Lower Falls stairway with three friends.

Read more

Photo: New York State Police

November 20, 2013

State trooper Ross M. Riley, a 44-year-old father of three, died after he became untethered from his safety line and tumbled backward off a ledge, falling about 30 feet to the base of the gorge in Wolf Creek. The accident occurred during a training mission to simulate the rescue of a person stranded in dangerous circumstances.

Read more

User submitted photo | Courtney Leighh

February 5, 2014

Stephen Bzibziak, a 21-year-old man from North Tonawanda, called 911 after falling into the Genesee River Gorge while hiking alone. Members of the State Park Police rope rescue team found the victim's body in the gorge. Bzibziak suffered multiple injuries as a result of the fall, including a broken leg, and died shortly after making the 911 call.

Read more

October 10, 2014

A 14-year-old boy died after falling 200 feet over Letchworth Gorge while hiking. Matthew Rezsnyak, from Rochester, was hiking with a friend and an adult along Trail 1 near the Great Bend Overlook when he fell along one of the deepest, most treacherous sections of the gorge flanking the Genesee River at the state park.

Read more

Provided photo

June 10, 2016

A balloon handler for Balloons Over Letchworth, a popular hot air balloon service at Letchworth, died near the state park following an accident in Nunda. State police said 34-year-old Ryan Almeter was holding onto the basket as passengers were getting off when wind caused the balloon to take flight. As the balloon reached about 100 feet in the air, Almeter let go and fell to his death.

Read more

Photo courtesy Matt Champlin

June 11, 2016

Seven people went over the Lower Falls of the Genesee River in the state park. Two brothers, 6-year-old Preston Giangregorio and 9-year-old Dylan Giangregorio , died, and the other five were rescued. State police said they had been playing in a restricted area near the Lower Falls when one person fell in the water. The commotion caused more to fall as they tried to help each other.

Read more

READ MORE: Relive infamous murder of Grace Brown in Adirondacks
